name: Buddhist Mythology
description: An enlightened being who delays entry into final nirvana in order to help all sentient beings achieve liberation. The bodhisattva ideal is central to Mahayana Buddhism. Major bodhisattvas include Avalokiteshvara (compassion) and Manjushri (wisdom).

philosophicalMeaning.selfSacrifice: The bodhisattva's postponement of nirvana mirrors the philosophical concept of kenosis - self-emptying for others' benefit
philosophicalMeaning.universalSalvation: The aspiration to liberate all beings reflects a universalist soteriology parallel to certain Christian theological traditions
philosophicalMeaning.meritTransfer: Bodhisattva merit dedication parallels the Christian concept of intercessory prayer and the treasury of merit
philosophicalMeaning.infiniteCompassion: The inexhaustible compassion of bodhisattvas corresponds philosophically to the theological concept of divine love (agape)

theologicalSignificance.christologicalParallel: The bodhisattva ideal bears striking resemblance to Christ as the one who, 'though he was in the form of God, did not count equality with God a thing to be grasped, but emptied himself' (Philippians 2:6-7)
theologicalSignificance.incarnationalTheology: Just as bodhisattvas remain in samsara to help beings, Christ took on human nature to dwell among humanity
theologicalSignificance.vicariousSuffering: The bodhisattva's willingness to bear suffering for others echoes Isaiah's Suffering Servant and substitutionary atonement theology
theologicalSignificance.mediatorRole: Bodhisattvas function as mediators between the unenlightened and enlightenment, similar to Christ as mediator between God and humanity (1 Timothy 2:5)

practicalApplications: The bodhisattva path offers a framework for understanding self-sacrificial love that resonates with Christian ethics of neighbor-love and service
definition: An enlightened being in Mahayana Buddhism who postpones final Nirvana to help all sentient beings achieve liberation, embodying the ideal of compassionate self-sacrifice and unlimited service.
practitioners: All followers of the Bodhisattva path
applications: Meditation on universal suffering and its cessation
Transformation of enlightenment for communal benefit

christian.kenosis: The self-emptying of the bodhisattva parallels Christ's kenosis (Philippians 2:5-11), where divine prerogatives are set aside for salvific purposes
christian.sufferingServant: Isaiah 53's Suffering Servant who bears the sins of many finds resonance in the bodhisattva who takes on the suffering of all beings
christian.universalRedemption: The bodhisattva vow to save all beings before oneself echoes the universalist hope expressed in 1 Timothy 2:4 that God 'desires all people to be saved'
christian.intercessoryPrayer: The bodhisattva's dedication of merit for others parallels the Christian practice of intercessory prayer and the Communion of Saints
christian.incarnationalPresence: Remaining in the world to help others reflects the Incarnation's logic - divine compassion entering human condition

comparativeNotes.naturalTheology: The bodhisattva ideal represents a natural apprehension of self-sacrificial love written on the human heart (Romans 2:14-15), pointing toward the fuller revelation in Christ

patristicCommentary.clementOfAlexandria: Clement recognized seeds of the Logos (logoi spermatikoi) in non-Christian philosophies, applicable to the Buddhist apprehension of selfless compassion
patristicCommentary.justinMartyr: Justin's concept of the 'seminal Word' present in all truth-seekers suggests divine preparation in the bodhisattva ideal
patristicCommentary.modernEngagement: Catholic theologians like Henri de Lubac and Hans Urs von Balthasar have explored resonances between bodhisattva spirituality and Christian kenotic theology

biblicalParallels: Philippians 2:5-11 - Christ's self-emptying (kenosis) for humanity's salvation
Isaiah 53 - The Suffering Servant bearing the iniquities of many
John 10:11 - The Good Shepherd who lays down his life for the sheep
1 Timothy 2:5 - Christ as the one mediator between God and humanity
Galatians 6:2 - Bearing one another's burdens fulfills the law of Christ
Romans 9:3 - Paul's willingness to be accursed for the sake of his kinsmen
typologicalReading: The bodhisattva may be understood typologically as a preparatio evangelica - a divine preparation in Asian spiritual thought pointing toward the fullness of self-sacrificial love revealed in Christ's passion and resurrection
